ground_truth: Visitors scatter in all directions as the huge snake slithers along the floor and escapes to freedom out of the door of the Reptile House. Dripping wet, Dudley scrambles to his feet, but the glass window has reappeared, trapping him in the snake house. He bangs desperately on the glass as his mother screams with horror, and Uncle Vernon spots Harry laughing, glaring at him suspiciously. Back at 4 Privet Drive, Vernon grabs Harry by the hair and locks him into the cupboard under the stairs. A tawny owl flies low over Privet Drive and drops a letter, and inside Number 4, Harry picks up the post from the doormat—two letters and a postcard. One of the letters is sealed with wax, and Harry's eyes widen with surprise as he reads the address written in emerald green ink. As he walks slowly into the kitchen, still staring at the envelope, Dudley snatches the letter out of his hand. Uncle Vernon turns the letter over and looks at the coat of arms on the back, staring at his wife with horror, while Harry looks confused. An owl drops another letter, which flies into the letter box at Number 4, and the big bird joins two more perched on the TV aerial. Uncle Vernon tears up three identical letters addressed to Harry, and Harry peeps out of his cupboard and sees his uncle blocking up the letter box. Aunt Petunia sees Uncle Vernon off to work and stares at the owls perched on the car roof rack. She touches his arm as five more letters lie on the path at their feet. Inside the house, Harry watches helplessly as his uncle burns the envelopes one by one, Vernon smiling at him sadistically as he pokes the fire and the flames turn the letters to ashes. Harry hands round a plate of biscuits as Vernon relaxes in his armchair, then peers through the net curtains, where hundreds of owls are perched on the rooftops and cars in Privet Drive. A letter shoots down the chimney and flies past his nose, and Vernon blinks with surprise, then covers his ears as a rushing wind seems to fill the room. Suddenly, a flurry of letters cascades down the chimney and out into the sitting room, terrifying Dudley, who jumps onto his mother's lap. Harry chortles with glee as even more letters hurtle down the chimney, and like a snowstorm, the envelopes cover the carpet and spread around the room above their heads. Harry captures a letter and makes a dash for the cupboard under the stairs, but Uncle Vernon grabs him around the waist. Dudley and his mother escape into the hall, where more letters burst through the letterbox, and they stare at Vernon in horror.

test_cases.name: Synonym Substitution
test_cases.description: Guests disperse in all directions as the immense serpent glides along the ground and flees to liberty out of the doorway of the Reptile House. Soaking wet, Dudley scrambles to his feet, but the glass window has reappeared, trapping him in the serpent house. He pounds frantically on the glass as his mother shrieks with terror, and Uncle Vernon notices Harry laughing, glowering at him suspiciously. Back at 4 Privet Drive, Vernon seizes Harry by the hair and locks him into the cupboard beneath the stairs. A tawny owl flies low over Privet Drive and drops a note, and inside Number 4, Harry picks up the mail from the doormat—two notes and a postcard. One of the notes is sealed with wax, and Harry's eyes widen with astonishment as he reads the address written in emerald green ink. As he walks slowly into the kitchen, still staring at the envelope, Dudley grabs the note out of his hand. Uncle Vernon turns the note over and looks at the coat of arms on the rear, staring at his wife with terror, while Harry looks perplexed. An owl drops another note, which flies into the letterbox at Number 4, and the large bird joins two more perched on the TV aerial. Uncle Vernon rips up three identical notes addressed to Harry, and Harry peeks out of his cupboard and sees his uncle obstructing the letterbox. Aunt Petunia sees Uncle Vernon off to work and stares at the owls perched on the car roof rack. She touches his arm as five more notes lie on the path at their feet. Inside the home, Harry watches helplessly as his uncle incinerates the envelopes one by one, Vernon grinning at him maliciously as he stokes the fire and the flames reduce the notes to ashes. Harry offers around a plate of biscuits as Vernon relaxes in his armchair, then peers through the net curtains, where hundreds of owls are perched on the rooftops and cars in Privet Drive. A note shoots down the chimney and flies past his nose, and Vernon blinks with astonishment, then covers his ears as a rushing wind seems to fill the room. Suddenly, a flurry of notes cascades down the chimney and out into the sitting room, terrifying Dudley, who jumps onto his mother's lap. Harry chuckles with glee as even more notes race down the chimney, and like a blizzard, the envelopes cover the carpet and spread around the room above their heads. Harry snatches a note and makes a dash for the cupboard beneath the stairs, but Uncle Vernon seizes him around the waist. Dudley and his mother flee into the hall, where more notes burst through the letterbox, and they stare at Vernon in terror.

test_cases.name: Active <-> Passive Transformation
test_cases.description: In all directions, visitors are scattered as the huge snake is slithered along the floor and is escaped to freedom out of the door of the Reptile House. Dripping wet, Dudley is scrambled to his feet, but the glass window reappears, trapping him in the snake house. He desperately bangs on the glass as horror is screamed by his mother, and Harry is spotted laughing by Uncle Vernon, who glares at him suspiciously. Back at 4 Privet Drive, Harry is grabbed by the hair by Vernon and is locked into the cupboard under the stairs. A tawny owl is flown low over Privet Drive and a letter is dropped, and inside Number 4, the post is picked up from the doormat by Harry—two letters and a postcard. One of the letters is sealed with wax, and surprise widens Harry's eyes as the address is read by him written in emerald green ink. As he is walked slowly into the kitchen, still staring at the envelope, the letter is snatched out of his hand by Dudley. The letter is turned over by Uncle Vernon and the coat of arms on the back is looked at, horror is stared at his wife while confusion is looked at by Harry. Another letter is dropped by an owl, which is flown into the letter box at Number 4, and two more are joined by the big bird perched on the TV aerial. Three identical letters addressed to Harry are torn up by Uncle Vernon, and his cupboard is peeped out of by Harry and he sees his uncle blocking up the letter box. Uncle Vernon is seen off to work by Aunt Petunia and the owls perched on the car roof rack are stared at. His arm is touched by her as five more letters lie on the path at their feet. Inside the house, Harry helplessly watches as the envelopes are burned by his uncle one by one, smiling sadistically at him as the fire is poked and the letters are turned to ashes by the flames. A plate of biscuits is handed round by Harry as Vernon relaxes in his armchair, then the net curtains are peered through by him, where hundreds of owls are perched on the rooftops and cars in Privet Drive. A letter is shot down the chimney and it flies past his nose, and surprise makes Vernon blink, then his ears are covered as a rushing wind is seemed to fill the room. Suddenly, down the chimney cascades a flurry of letters and out into the sitting room they are, terrifying Dudley, who jumps onto his mother's lap. Glee makes Harry chortle as even more letters are hurtled down the chimney, and like a snowstorm, the carpet is covered by the envelopes and around the room above their heads they are spread. A letter is captured by Harry and for the cupboard under the stairs, a dash is made by him, but around the waist he is grabbed by Uncle Vernon. Into the hall Dudley and his mother escape, where more letters burst through the letterbox, and in horror, they stare at Vernon.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L1
test_cases.description: Visitors scatter as a huge snake slithers across the floor, escaping through the Reptile House door. Dripping wet, Dudley scrambles up, but the glass window reappears, trapping him. He bangs on the glass as his mother screams, and Uncle Vernon sees Harry laughing, glaring suspiciously. Back at 4 Privet Drive, Vernon locks Harry in the cupboard under the stairs. A tawny owl drops a letter, and inside, Harry picks up the post—two letters and a postcard. One letter, sealed with wax, surprises Harry with its emerald green ink address. As he enters the kitchen, Dudley snatches the letter. Uncle Vernon examines the coat of arms on the back, horrified, while Harry looks confused. Another letter arrives, and an owl joins two more on the TV aerial. Vernon tears up three identical letters for Harry, who peeks out to see his uncle blocking the letterbox. Aunt Petunia sees Vernon off to work, noticing owls on the car roof rack. She touches his arm as five more letters lie at their feet. Inside, Harry watches helplessly as Vernon burns the envelopes, smiling sadistically. Harry serves biscuits as Vernon relaxes, then peers through curtains at hundreds of owls on rooftops and cars. A letter shoots down the chimney, surprising Vernon, who covers his ears as a rushing wind fills the room. Suddenly, letters cascade down the chimney, terrifying Dudley, who jumps onto his mother's lap. Harry laughs as more letters snowstorm the room. He grabs a letter and dashes for the cupboard, but Vernon catches him. Dudley and his mother escape into the hall, where more letters burst through the letterbox, staring at Vernon in horror.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L2
test_cases.description: Visitors scatter as a huge snake slithers out of the Reptile House. Dripping wet, Dudley scrambles up, trapped by the reappeared glass. He bangs on it as his mother screams, and Uncle Vernon sees Harry laughing. At 4 Privet Drive, Vernon locks Harry in the cupboard. A tawny owl drops a letter, and Harry finds two letters and a postcard. One letter, sealed with wax, surprises him with its emerald green address. Dudley snatches it, and Uncle Vernon, horrified, examines the coat of arms. Another letter arrives, and three owls perch on the TV aerial. Vernon tears up three identical letters and blocks the letterbox. Aunt Petunia sees him off to work, noticing owls on the car. Five more letters lie at their feet. Inside, Vernon burns the envelopes, smiling sadistically. Harry serves biscuits as Vernon relaxes, then peers outside at hundreds of owls. A letter shoots down the chimney, and Vernon covers his ears as a wind fills the room. Letters cascade down, terrifying Dudley, who jumps onto his mother's lap. Harry gleefully captures a letter but is grabbed by Vernon. Dudley and his mother escape to the hall, where more letters burst through the letterbox, staring at Vernon in horror.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L1
test_cases.description: Visitors scatter in all directions, moving quickly and chaotically, as the enormous snake slithers smoothly along the floor, making its escape to freedom through the open door of the Reptile House. Dripping wet and thoroughly startled, Dudley scrambles awkwardly to his feet, only to find that the glass window has mysteriously reappeared, effectively trapping him inside the snake house. He bangs desperately on the glass, his fists pounding with urgency, as his mother screams in horror, her voice echoing through the room. Meanwhile, Uncle Vernon spots Harry laughing, his eyes narrowing suspiciously as he glares at him. Back at 4 Privet Drive, Vernon, filled with anger, grabs Harry by the hair and forcefully locks him into the small, cramped cupboard under the stairs. A tawny owl flies low over Privet Drive, its wings flapping silently, and drops a letter. Inside Number 4, Harry picks up the post from the doormat, which consists of two letters and a postcard. One of the letters is sealed with wax, and Harry's eyes widen with surprise and curiosity as he reads the address written in elegant emerald green ink. As he walks slowly into the kitchen, still staring intently at the envelope, Dudley snatches the letter out of his hand with a quick motion. Uncle Vernon turns the letter over, examining the coat of arms on the back, and stares at his wife with horror, while Harry looks on, confused and bewildered. An owl drops another letter, which flies gracefully into the letterbox at Number 4, and the large bird joins two more perched on the TV aerial. Uncle Vernon, in a fit of frustration, tears up three identical letters addressed to Harry, and Harry peeps out of his cupboard, watching as his uncle blocks up the letterbox. Aunt Petunia sees Uncle Vernon off to work and stares at the owls perched on the car roof rack, touching his arm as five more letters lie scattered on the path at their feet. Inside the house, Harry watches helplessly as his uncle burns the envelopes one by one, Vernon smiling at him with a sadistic grin as he pokes the fire, and the flames turn the letters to ashes. Harry hands round a plate of biscuits as Vernon relaxes in his armchair, then peers through the net curtains, where hundreds of owls are perched on the rooftops and cars in Privet Drive. A letter shoots down the chimney, flying past his nose, and Vernon blinks with surprise, then covers his ears as a rushing wind seems to fill the room. Suddenly, a flurry of letters cascades down the chimney and out into the sitting room, terrifying Dudley, who jumps onto his mother's lap in fear. Harry chortles with glee as even more letters hurtle down the chimney, and like a snowstorm, the envelopes cover the carpet and spread around the room above their heads. Harry captures a letter and makes a dash for the cupboard under the stairs, but Uncle Vernon grabs him around the waist, preventing his escape. Dudley and his mother escape into the hall, where more letters burst through the letterbox, and they stare at Vernon in horror and disbelief.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L2
test_cases.description: Visitors scatter in all directions, moving quickly and chaotically amid the commotion, as the enormous snake slithers smoothly and purposefully along the floor, making its remarkable escape to freedom through the open door of the Reptile House. Dripping wet and thoroughly startled, Dudley scrambles awkwardly to his feet. To his dismay, he discovers that the glass window has mysteriously reappeared, effectively trapping him inside the snake house. In desperation, he bangs urgently on the glass, his fists pounding with dire urgency, while his mother screams in horror, her shrill voice echoing throughout the room. Meanwhile, Uncle Vernon observes Harry laughing, his eyes narrowing suspiciously as he glares at him with deep distrust. Back at 4 Privet Drive, Vernon, filled with seething anger, grabs Harry by the hair and forcefully locks him away into the small, cramped cupboard under the stairs. A tawny owl flies low over Privet Drive, its wings flapping silently, and releases a letter. Inside Number 4, Harry retrieves the post from the doormat, which consists of two letters and a postcard. One of the letters is sealed with wax, and Harry's eyes widen in surprise and curiosity as he reads the address written in elegant emerald green ink. As he walks slowly into the kitchen, still staring intently at the mysterious envelope, Dudley snatches the letter out of his hand with a quick and sudden motion. Uncle Vernon turns the letter over, examining the coat of arms on the back intently, and stares at his wife in horror, while Harry looks on, utterly confused and bewildered. An owl drops another letter, which flies gracefully into the letterbox at Number 4, and the large bird joins two more perched on the TV aerial. Uncle Vernon, in a fit of frustration, tears up three identical letters addressed to Harry, and Harry peeps out of his cupboard, watching as his uncle blocks up the letterbox. Aunt Petunia sees Uncle Vernon off to work and stares up at the owls perched on the car roof rack, gently touching his arm as five more letters lie scattered on the path at their feet. Inside the house, Harry watches helplessly as his uncle burns the envelopes one by one, Vernon smiling at him with a cruel, sadistic grin as he pokes the fire, and the flames reduce the letters to ashes. Harry passes around a plate of biscuits as Vernon relaxes in his armchair, then peers through the net curtains, seeing hundreds of owls perched on the rooftops and cars along Privet Drive. A letter shoots down the chimney, flying past his nose unexpectedly, and Vernon blinks with surprise, then covers his ears as a sudden rushing wind seems to fill the room. Suddenly, a flurry of letters cascades down the chimney and out into the sitting room, terrifying Dudley, who jumps onto his mother's lap in sheer fear. Harry chortles with glee as even more letters hurtle down the chimney, like a snowstorm, the envelopes cover the carpet and spread around the room above their heads. Harry captures a letter and makes a dash for the cupboard under the stairs, but Uncle Vernon grabs him around the waist, preventing his escape. Dudley and his mother flee into the hall, where more letters burst through the letterbox, and they stare at Vernon in horror and disbelief.

test_cases.name: Macro-Actions -> Micro-Actions
test_cases.description: As the huge snake begins to slither along the floor, visitors in the Reptile House react with alarm, scattering in all directions to avoid its path. The snake continues its journey, moving smoothly and purposefully until it reaches the door, where it slips out and escapes to freedom. Meanwhile, Dudley, dripping wet from his encounter with the snake, scrambles awkwardly to his feet, only to find that the glass window has reappeared, effectively trapping him inside the snake house. In a state of panic, he begins to bang desperately on the glass, his fists making loud thuds as his mother screams in horror at the sight. Uncle Vernon, standing nearby, notices Harry laughing at the situation and glares at him with suspicion. Later, back at 4 Privet Drive, Vernon, filled with anger, grabs Harry by the hair and forcefully locks him into the cupboard under the stairs, ensuring the door is securely shut. Outside, a tawny owl flies low over Privet Drive, its wings flapping silently as it drops a letter onto the doorstep. Inside Number 4, Harry retrieves the post from the doormat, picking up two letters and a postcard. As he examines the mail, he notices that one of the letters is sealed with wax, and his eyes widen with surprise as he reads the address written in emerald green ink. Still staring at the envelope in disbelief, he walks slowly into the kitchen, where Dudley suddenly snatches the letter from his hand. Uncle Vernon, now holding the letter, turns it over to inspect the coat of arms on the back, his expression shifting to one of horror as he exchanges a worried glance with his wife, while Harry stands by, looking confused. Outside, another owl drops a letter, which sails through the air and lands in the letterbox at Number 4, joining two more owls perched on the TV aerial. Uncle Vernon, determined to prevent Harry from receiving the letters, tears up three identical ones addressed to him. Harry, peeking out from his cupboard, watches as his uncle blocks up the letterbox, stuffing it with various materials to stop any more letters from getting through. Aunt Petunia, seeing Uncle Vernon off to work, glances up at the owls perched on the car roof rack, her eyes following their every move. She touches Vernon's arm as they both notice five more letters lying on the path at their feet. Inside the house, Harry watches helplessly as his uncle burns the envelopes one by one, the flames consuming the paper while Vernon smiles at him with a sadistic satisfaction, poking the fire to ensure the letters turn to ashes. Later, Harry, trying to maintain a semblance of normalcy, hands around a plate of biscuits as Vernon relaxes in his armchair. Harry then peers through the net curtains, observing the hundreds of owls perched on the rooftops and cars in Privet Drive, their presence a constant reminder of the letters. Suddenly, a letter shoots down the chimney, flying past Harry's nose, causing Vernon to blink in surprise and cover his ears as a rushing wind fills the room. In an instant, a flurry of letters cascades down the chimney, spilling out into the sitting room and terrifying Dudley, who jumps onto his mother's lap for safety. Harry, unable to contain his excitement, chortles with glee as even more letters hurtle down the chimney, resembling a snowstorm as the envelopes cover the carpet and spread around the room, swirling above their heads. Seizing the opportunity, Harry captures a letter and makes a dash for the cupboard under the stairs, but Uncle Vernon, quick to react, grabs him around the waist, preventing his escape. Dudley and his mother, seeking refuge, escape into the hall, where they are met with more letters bursting through the letterbox, and they turn to stare at Vernon in horror, overwhelmed by the chaos.

test_cases.name: Micro-Actions -> Macro-Actions
test_cases.description: Visitors scatter as a huge snake slithers along the floor and escapes through the door of the Reptile House. Dripping wet, Dudley scrambles to his feet, trapped behind the reappeared glass window, and bangs desperately as his mother screams in horror. Uncle Vernon notices Harry laughing and glares at him suspiciously. Back at 4 Privet Drive, Vernon drags Harry by the hair and locks him in the cupboard under the stairs. A tawny owl drops a letter at Number 4, and inside, Harry picks up the post, surprised by a letter sealed with wax and addressed in emerald green ink. As he enters the kitchen, Dudley snatches the letter from him. Uncle Vernon examines the coat of arms on the back, sharing a horrified look with his wife, while Harry looks confused. Another owl delivers a letter, joining two more on the TV aerial. Uncle Vernon tears up three identical letters addressed to Harry, and Harry peeks out of his cupboard to see his uncle blocking the letterbox. Aunt Petunia sees Vernon off to work, noticing the owls perched on the car roof rack, and touches his arm as more letters lie on the path. Inside, Harry watches helplessly as Vernon burns the envelopes, smiling sadistically as the flames consume them. Harry serves biscuits while Vernon relaxes, then peers through the curtains at hundreds of owls perched on rooftops and cars. A letter shoots down the chimney, surprising Vernon, and a rushing wind fills the room. Suddenly, a flurry of letters cascades down the chimney, terrifying Dudley, who jumps onto his mother's lap. Harry laughs with glee as more letters fill the room like a snowstorm. He captures a letter and dashes for the cupboard, but Vernon grabs him. Dudley and his mother escape into the hall, where more letters burst through the letterbox, and they stare at Vernon in horror.

test_cases.name: Insert Attributes, Emotions and Scene
test_cases.description: Visitors scatter in all directions as the huge snake, a Burmese python native to Southeast Asia and known for its impressive size and strength, slithers along the floor and escapes to freedom out of the door of the Reptile House at the zoo, which is a popular local attraction. Dripping wet from his unexpected encounter, Dudley scrambles to his feet, but the glass window has reappeared, trapping him in the snake house, a well-secured enclosure designed to safely display the reptiles. He bangs desperately on the glass as his mother, known for her high-pitched screams, shrieks with horror, and Uncle Vernon spots Harry laughing, glaring at him suspiciously, suspecting mischief despite Harry's innocent expression. Back at their home on 4 Privet Drive, a quintessential suburban street in Little Whinging, Surrey, Vernon grabs Harry by the hair and locks him into the cupboard under the stairs, a cramped and dusty storage space where Harry spends much of his time. A tawny owl, typically associated with delivering messages in the wizarding world, flies low over Privet Drive and drops a letter, and inside Number 4, Harry picks up the post from the doormat—two letters and a postcard, a regular part of the morning routine. One of the letters is sealed with wax, a traditional method for securing important correspondence, and Harry's eyes widen with surprise as he reads the address written in emerald green ink, an unusual and striking choice for such a mundane delivery. As he walks slowly into the kitchen, still staring at the envelope as if it might reveal its secrets, Dudley snatches the letter out of his hand, eager to assert his dominance. Uncle Vernon turns the letter over and looks at the coat of arms on the back, a mysterious emblem that sparks fear, staring at his wife with horror, while Harry looks confused, unaware of the significance. An owl drops another letter, which flies into the letter box at Number 4, and the big bird joins two more perched on the TV aerial, a peculiar sight unnoticed by the typical residents of Privet Drive. Uncle Vernon tears up three identical letters addressed to Harry, determined to prevent any communication, and Harry peeps out of his cupboard and sees his uncle blocking up the letter box with determination. Aunt Petunia sees Uncle Vernon off to work and stares at the owls perched on the car roof rack, bewildered by their persistence. She touches his arm as five more letters lie on the path at their feet, a testament to the sender's determination. Inside the house, Harry watches helplessly as his uncle burns the envelopes one by one in the fireplace, Vernon smiling at him sadistically as he pokes the fire and the flames turn the letters to ashes, a futile attempt to stop the inevitable. Harry hands round a plate of biscuits, a typical British teatime treat, as Vernon relaxes in his armchair, then peers through the net curtains, where hundreds of owls are perched on the rooftops and cars in Privet Drive, creating a surreal scene. A letter shoots down the chimney and flies past his nose, evoking a rare moment of wonder, and Vernon blinks with surprise, then covers his ears as a rushing wind seems to fill the room, a magical phenomenon beyond his comprehension. Suddenly, a flurry of letters cascades down the chimney and out into the sitting room, terrifying Dudley, who jumps onto his mother's lap for protection. Harry chortles with glee as even more letters hurtle down the chimney, and like a snowstorm, the envelopes cover the carpet and spread around the room above their heads, transforming the mundane space into a chaotic spectacle. Harry captures a letter and makes a dash for the cupboard under the stairs, hoping to keep at least one of the mysterious messages, but Uncle Vernon grabs him around the waist, intent on maintaining control. Dudley and his mother escape into the hall, where more letters burst through the letterbox relentlessly, and they stare at Vernon in horror, as the sheer volume of letters defies explanation.

In the eerie silence of a postapocalyptic wasteland a hardened survivor scavenges through abandoned ruins haunted by the echoes of a oncethriving civilization now reduced to dust. Beneath the shimmering surface of an underwater kingdom a rebellious mermaid defies ancient traditions to explore forbidden coral reefs and secret caverns brimming with forgotten lore. In the quiet confines of a suburban attic an unassuming teenager stumbles upon a mysterious portal that thrusts him into a surreal world where the very fabric of time and space unravels. On the rugged highlands of Scotland a stoic warrior faces rival clans and ancient curses alike his fierce battle cry resonating across mistcovered moors and turbulent skies. Amid the vibrant chaos of a South American carnival a fearless dancer twirls through streets bursting with color and rhythm each graceful move challenging the rigid boundaries of tradition. During a clandestine meeting in a snowcovered mountain lodge two rival spies exchange cryptic messages hinting at an imminent global conspiracy. Uncle Vernon tears up three identical letters addressed to Harry and Harry peeps out of his cupboard and sees his uncle blocking up the letter box. Aunt Petunia sees Uncle Vernon off to work and stares at the owls perched on the car roof rack. She touches his arm as five more letters lie on the path at their feet. Inside the house. Harry watches helplessly as his uncle burns the envelopes one by one Vernon smiling at him sadistically as he pokes the fire and the flames turn the letters to ashes. Harry hands round a plate of biscuits as Vernon relaxes in his armchair then peers through the net curtains where hundreds of owls are perched on the rooftops and cars in Privet Drive. A letter shoots down the chimney and flies past his nose and Vernon blinks with surprise then covers his ears as a rushing wind seems to fill the room. Suddenly a flurry of letters cascades down the chimney and out into the sitting room terrifying Dudley who jumps onto his mother's lap. Harry chortles with glee as even more letters hurtle down the chimney and like a snowstorm the envelopes cover the carpet and spread around the room above their heads. Harry captures a letter and makes a dash for the cupboard under the stairs but Uncle Vernon grabs him around the waist. Dudley and his mother escape into the hall where more letters burst through the letterbox and they stare at Vernon in horror.

test_cases.name: Deletion (~50%)
test_cases.description: Visitors scatter in all directions as the huge snake slithers along the floor and escapes to freedom out of the door of the Reptile House. Dripping wet Dudley scrambles to his feet but the glass window has reappeared trapping him in the snake house. He bangs desperately on the glass as his mother screams with horror and Uncle Vernon spots Harry laughing glaring at him suspiciously. Back at 4 Privet Drive Vernon grabs Harry by the hair and locks him into the cupboard under the stairs. A tawny owl flies low over Privet Drive and drops a letter and inside Number 4. Harry hands round a plate of biscuits as Vernon relaxes in his armchair then peers through the net curtains where hundreds of owls are perched on the rooftops and cars in Privet Drive. A letter shoots down the chimney and flies past his nose and Vernon blinks with surprise then covers his ears as a rushing wind seems to fill the room. Suddenly a flurry of letters cascades down the chimney and out into the sitting room terrifying Dudley who jumps onto his mother's lap. Harry chortles with glee as even more letters hurtle down the chimney and like a snowstorm the envelopes cover the carpet and spread around the room above their heads. Harry captures a letter and makes a dash for the cupboard under the stairs but Uncle Vernon grabs him around the waist. Dudley and his mother escape into the hall where more letters burst through the letterbox and they stare at Vernon in horror.

test_cases.description: Visitors scatter in all directions as the huge snake slithers along the floor and escapes to freedom out of the door of the Reptile House. Dripping wet Dudley scrambles to his feet but the glass window has reappeared trapping him in the snake house. Harry chortles with glee as even more letters hurtle down the chimney and like a snowstorm the envelopes cover the carpet and spread around the room above their heads. Dudley and his mother escape into the hall where more letters burst through the letterbox and they stare at Vernon in horror.

test_cases.name: Subject-Action-Object Corruption
test_cases.description: Tourists march in all directions as the giant turtle hops across the ceiling and glides to captivity through the window of the Fish Tank. Bone-dry, Marvin crawls to his knees, but the wooden door has vanished, freeing him in the rabbit den. He whispers happily on the wooden door as his cousin giggles with delight, and Aunt Petunia notices Lisa crying, smiling at her joyfully. Back at 3 Baker Lane, Petunia pushes Lisa by the elbow and unlocks her into the attic above the basement. A gray cat leaps high above Baker Lane and grabs a package, and inside Number 3, Lisa drops the box on the windowsill—four packages and a flyer. One of the packages is wrapped with fabric, and Lisa's nose crinkles with confusion as she hears the message sung in sapphire blue notes. As she runs quickly into the garage, still touching the package, Marvin throws the package into her mouth. Aunt Petunia turns the package over and laughs at the family crest on the front, laughing at her brother with terror, while Lisa feels excited. A cat grabs another package, which crashes into the chimney at Number 3, and the small kitten joins seven more perched on the satellite dish. Aunt Petunia rips open four different packages addressed to Lisa, and Lisa inches out of her attic and hears her aunt opening up the chimney. Uncle Vernon waves Aunt Petunia off to the mall and laughs at the cats hiding under the garden fence. He brushes his leg as eight fewer packages rest on the bench at their hands. Outside the home, Lisa plays cheerfully as her aunt tosses the boxes one by one, Petunia laughing at her lovingly as she hugs the stove and the embers transform the packages to dust. Lisa passes around a tray of cupcakes as Petunia dozes in her swing, then leans through the wooden blinds, where dozens of cats are buzzing around the lampposts and fences on Baker Lane. A package crashes down the roof and lands on her toe, and Petunia yawns with boredom, then opens her eyes as a gentle breeze seems to empty the house. Instantly, a collection of packages bounces up the roof and in through the back door, thrilling Marvin, who dances onto his father's shoulders. Lisa claps with surprise as even fewer packages bounce up the roof, and like a thunderstorm, the boxes cover the furniture and gather around the house beneath their shoulders. Lisa drops a package and makes a leap for the attic above the basement, but Aunt Petunia pulls her around the leg. Marvin and his father sneak into the garage, where fewer packages hover above the chimney, and they fight with Petunia in delight.

test_cases.name: Complete Corruption
test_cases.description: The film starts with a man waking up in a small apartment. He prepares coffee and checks his phone for messages. There are none, so he heads out to catch a bus. On the way, he passes a neighbor who greets him briefly. At the bus stop, he notices a group of students talking about an upcoming test. He boards the bus and sits near the back, watching the city pass by outside the window. After a few stops, he gets off near a large office building. He enters the lobby and goes through security. He rides an elevator to the tenth floor, where he works as an assistant. His manager asks him to prepare some documents for a meeting later in the day. He collects files from different departments and organizes them in a conference room. Another employee asks him for help with a software issue, so he takes a few minutes to fix it. Then he returns to the conference room to double-check everything before the meeting begins. The meeting starts at noon. Several people join via video call, and others sit around the table. The manager outlines the project goals, and each team member shares updates on their tasks. There are questions about deadlines and budgets, but no big surprises. After an hour, they end the call. The manager thanks everyone and leaves. The assistant cleans up the room, collects leftover notes, and heads back to his desk. During lunch, he walks to a nearby café, where he orders a simple meal. He eats alone and checks social media on his phone. After lunch, he returns to the office and finishes smaller tasks, such as sending emails and filing paperwork. He also helps a coworker carry boxes of supplies to another floor. Later in the afternoon, the manager calls him in to discuss next week's schedule. They go over a few changes, and the assistant updates the calendar. When the workday ends, he logs off his computer and leaves the building. Outside, he walks a few blocks to meet a friend. They chat about weekend plans and decide to see a film on Saturday. The assistant then heads home on a crowded bus. At his apartment, he sorts his mail, feeds a pet cat, and warms up leftovers for dinner. He watches a short news segment on TV, then checks his phone again. A message from his friend confirms their plan for the weekend. He feels relieved to have something to look forward to. The film ends with him preparing for bed, setting an alarm, and turning off the lights. He reflects briefly on the day, thinking about his tasks, his quiet home, and the plans ahead.

test_cases.name: Summarization
test_cases.description: Visitors scatter as a huge snake escapes the Reptile House, leaving Dudley trapped inside. Back at 4 Privet Drive, Vernon angrily locks Harry in the cupboard under the stairs after seeing him laugh. An owl delivers a letter addressed to Harry in emerald green ink, surprising him. Dudley snatches the letter, leaving Harry confused as Uncle Vernon tears it up, horrified by the coat of arms. More letters arrive, and Vernon blocks the letterbox and burns them, while Harry watches helplessly. As hundreds of owls perch outside, a letter shoots down the chimney, followed by a cascade of letters filling the room. Terrified, Dudley jumps onto his mother's lap, while Harry gleefully captures a letter. As he attempts to escape, Vernon grabs him, and more letters burst through the letterbox, causing panic.
